narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Special relativity, tensor algebra, covariant formulation of electrodynamics, and some applications.
I learned special relativity more in depth, and the introduction to tensors, both the math and notation, was all new.

This course reintroduced some of the concepts of special relativity from the prerequisites (PHYS 401 or 410), examined more thoroughly the interaction between electromagnetism and special relativity, and introduced tensors as a means of working in special relativity and as a prep for general relativity.
Aside from the direct course-related material, I importantly learned tensor notation, and how to manipulate tensors.
Special relativity  in mechanics and E&M, four vectors, tensor manipulation.

I developed a better understanding of special relativity and its consequences in the contexts of mechanics and electromagnetism. I also gained foundational exposure to working with four-vectors and tensors. We also discussed Lorentz transformations and their consequences in the context of special relativity in detail.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Maybe skip some of the algebra during the lecture itself to save more time for (more) physical insight.

This course was well organized and had a clear syllabus of what we were doing. I think one weakness was not having any textbook or notes for the class, as this meant there was no was to supplement the lectures. I usually like to have some other source of material.

The office hours were extraordinarily helpful, and the homework did a decent job of teaching the concepts (though the questions were often difficult to understand). I didn't really understand much at all until I did the homework. And that was the weakness: I really did not understand anything until I went to office hours and did the homework. Also, I wish the course had followed a textbook.
The course is well structured and well taught.

The course covers very interesting material and it is presented in an engaging format. The assignments are challenging and take a good amount of time to complete. However, since special relativity is challenging and counter-intuitive at times, I think the higher difficulty and length of the assignments is key and, in fact, beneficial to truly cementing one's understanding of the material. Furthermore, the nature of special relativity and its awesome consequences makes the assignments feel engaging and rewarding, especially when you arrive at a solution. Professor Skiba is also a wonderful lecturer and strives to make each class engaging by posing thoughtful questions and delving into the beauty of the theory. He is also incredibly helpful as he provides well-structured and comprehensive answers whenever students have questions.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The office hours and lectures were both helpful, which was aided by the very small class size.

The lectures in the virtual setting for some reason did not succeed in conveying the information to me. Also, to accommodate international students we had to have the midterm from 8 to 10 pm one night, which is a very less-than-ideal time. It would have been nice if there had been a different way around the time zone problem.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! SR has never been taught properly in either dynamics or EM class due to a lack of time. This is a great class to bridge that gap. Familiarity with covariant/contravariant tensor algebra built from this class is also helpful for learning GR in the future.
Yes. I think this was a really interesting course. It starts a little slow, but by the end I was doing completely new math and physics.
Yes

Unless you're really interested in relativity, I can't say I would recommend the course, at least as long as it is online. I was very lost conceptually for a long time, and had to supplement the course through internet research and heavy use of office hours as supplementary lectures.
I would recommend this course to students who are interested in learning about special relativity or are planning on taking courses such as general relativity.

I would highly recommend this course for any physics major looking to solidify their understanding of special relativity but has not yet had the chance to do so due to the fact that special relativity is lumped in at the end and lightly touched in their other physics course. This course is fairly challenging as special relativity is inherently challenging itself. However, if the right amount of time is dedicated, it is more than manageable. You will gain great insight learning from Professor Skiba that truly makes the course worth taking.
